author: Special Correspondent
text:
The city’s burning issues of traffic, garbage and pollution apparently raised a stink when the visiting Parliamentary Standing Committee on Environment and Forests met the Chief Minister, State officials and NGOs here on Thursday.

Panel chairman Ashwani Kumar expressed shock at the ineffective working of the State Pollution Control Board.

He said that the Parliamentarians were dismayed by the poor state of air and noise quality due to the city’s heavy vehicular traffic and poor handling of solid and biomedical waste. The Chief Minister has been urged to address all these and other environmental concerns of the city, he said.

“It is shocking to know that Bengaluru alone has about 9,000 clinical establishments but only three service providers to handle their biomedical waste, which is a health hazard. We have requested authorities to submit an action plan on collection and ways to deal with it,” Dr. Ashwani Kumar told a news conference here.

“We are disappointed and aghast to note that till date no effective enforcement measures seem to have been taken by the Pollution Control Board against those guilty of violating environmental norms. We learn that 211 prosecutions were launched but not one resulted in sentencing or even a fine. We have asked the [PCB] to come out with proposals to amend and make the law more effective,” the MP and former Union Minister said.

Stating that environment will be the nation’s biggest challenge after terrorism, Dr. Ashwani Kumar said the city's drinking water and its polluted and dying lakes were also discussed.

Instead of dumping garbage in the villages around it, the city should find the right way of disposing it, he said.
title: Bengaluru city waste, noise issues ‘shock’ MPs panel
